title: Prologis to buy warehouse rival in $US12.6b deal amid e-commerce boom
text:
Warehouse giant Prologis has agreed to acquire rival industrial real-estate business Liberty Property Trust in a $US12.6 billion ($18.5 billion) deal to improve its US presence amid the e-commerce boom.

If approved, Prologis said Liberty shareholders would receive 0.675 times a Prologis share for each unit they hold, about $US61 a share. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2020.

Prologis, which has a global footprint, said the all-stock deal including the assumption of debt would deepen its presence in US markets such as Pennsylvania's Lehigh Valley, Chicago, Houston, New Jersey and Southern California.

Prologis' customers include Amazon, Walmart and FedEx. Bloomberg

"Liberty’s logistics assets are highly complementary to our US portfolio and this acquisition increases our holdings and growth potential in several key markets," Prologis chairman and chief executive officer Hamid Moghadam said.

"The joining of these two platforms at this moment, when industrial logistics has become so pivotal to the new economy, will further the industry's ability to support the nation's supply chain," Liberty chairman and chief executive officer Bill Hankowsky said.
description: Prologis' customers include Amazon, Walmart and FedEx. The takeover will extend its footprint into a number of US markets.
